title: Hamas and Palestinian paramedics say Israeli airstrike kills 35 in Gaza's Rafah
summary: The airstrike hit tents for displaced Palestinians in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, and 'numerous' people were trapped in the flaming debris.

title: 'The ravages inflicted on higher education in Gaza can only favor Hamas'
summary: Universities in Gaza, attended by some 90,000 students before October 7, 2023, have all been destroyed or damaged.

title: New Caledonia: State of emergency to be lifted in efforts to allow political dialogue
summary: 480 additional gendarmes are to arrive on the archipelago 'in the next few hours.' The unrest has left seven people dead and a trail of destruction.

title: Homophobic ambushers are baiting and beating gay men across France
summary: It's hard to keep track of the number of assaults: Victims don't always come forward, and often struggle to have the attacks recognized as homophobic.

title: In Georgia, demonstrators ready themselves for a long fight: 'We don't want a new Maidan'
summary: At this stage, opponents of the 'foreign influence' bill are ruling out the possibility of revolution, hoping instead to oust the government at the ballot box in the October legislative elections.

title: François Hollande's love affair scooter auctioned off in French castle
summary: The famous vehicle at the center of a love affair between former French president François Hollande and actress Julie Gayet sold for €20,500 at an auction in France on Sunday.

title: Mayotte: Second person dies of cholera on French island
summary: A 62-year-old woman has died of cholera, bringing the death toll from the epidemic on the French island in the Indian Ocean to two, health authorities said on Sunday.

title: At least 15 dead in Texas, Oklahoma, and Arkansas after powerful storms in the region
summary: The storms inflicted their worst damage from north of Dallas to the northwest corner of Arkansas, and the system threatened to bring more violent weather to other parts of the Midwest later in the day and to the East Coast on Monday.

title: Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda re-elected in vote marked by Russia fears
summary: His opponent, Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte, conceded defeat in comments to reporters and congratulated Nauseda.

title: Dominique Méda: 'We need more EU'
summary: In her column, sociologist Dominique Méda argues that, beyond the criticisms leveled at Brussels, member states need a transnational space to debate and overcome their differences.

title: Macron begins first state visit to Germany by a French president in 24 years
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron was greeted on Sunday by German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier at the start of a three-day state visit.

title: Papua New Guinea landslide death toll now estimated at 670, says UN official
summary: The landslide struck in the early hours of Friday morning. 'There are an estimated 150-plus houses now buried,' said UN migration agency official Serhan Aktoprak.

title: Lyon: At least three injured in knife attack on metro
summary: Police said that an attacker has been arrested following the incident on Sunday. Three victims are being treated by emergency services, the regional prefecture said.

title: New Caledonia's Nouméa airport will remain closed to commercial flights until June 2
summary: The airport's operator said on Sunday that it would remain closed to commercial flights, extending the shutdown to nearly three weeks in total.

title: Lithuania votes in presidential election under Russian shadow
summary: The incumbent, President Gitanas Nauseda, elected for the first time in 2019, is widely favored over conservative Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte.

title: 'Let It Be': Peter Jackson and Disney bring Beatles documentary back from oblivion
summary: Released in 1970, Michael Lindsay-Hogg's documentary on The Beatles, which had not been seen for over half a century, was restored by Peter Jackson’s production company.

title: Cannes 2024: From New York to Tehran, winners worthy of a lush festival
summary: Greta Gerwig's jury gave the Palme d'Or to Sean Baker's 'Anora' and awarded the Best Actress Prize to the female cast of Jacques Audiard's 'Emilia Perez.' Iranian filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof, who fled Iran, received the Special Jury Prize.

title: Formula 1: Charles Leclerc wins first home Monaco Grand Prix
Protests in Armenia to call for PM resignation
summary: Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan agreed to hand over control of several border villages to Azerbaijan.

title: Rafael Nadal, king of clay, returns to French Open for last dance
summary: Long in doubt, his body battered by injury, the Spaniard begins his 19th tournament on Paris clay against Alexander Zverev on Monday. It will likely be his last.

title: In Bangladesh, cyclone floods coastal villages
summary: Nearly 800,000 residents had evacuated and hundreds of thousands of people were left without power on Monday. Authorities gave no casualty figures yet, but media reported that at least two people died.

title: Despite fatigue and setbacks, 'Ukrainians mobilized on the front have no intention of laying down their arms'
summary: After returning from Ukraine, where he has been covering the conflict since the start of the Russian invasion, Le Monde journalist Emmanuel Grynszpan answered reader questions in an online chat.

title: The Seine and other European rivers contaminated by a 'forever chemical' that has gone under the radar
summary: Analyses carried out by the Pesticide Action Network Europe (PAN Europe) in 10 EU countries show the widespread presence of high levels of trifluoroacetic acid, a member of the PFAS family.

title: Alexandra Roulet, 36-year-old professor, wins Best Young Economist Award
summary: The professor at INSEAD has served as an adviser to President Emmanuel Macron as well as the French prime minister's office.

title: Alexandra Roulet: 'The influence of economists is only real in the medium-to-long term'
summary: A professor at INSEAD, the winner of the Best Young Economist Award is a specialist in labor, unemployment insurance, employment policies, and gender inequality.

title: Papua New Guinea reports more than 2,000 people buried in landslide
summary: A remote hillside village in Enga province was almost wiped out when a chunk of Mount Mungalo collapsed in the early hours of Friday morning, burying scores of homes and the people sleeping inside them.

title: Paris by bike: 10 green islands from Porte de Versailles to the Jardins de Luxembourg
summary: Rue de Vaugirard, the longest street in Paris, offers a safe 4-kilometer cycle ride from the 15th to the 6th arrondissement. The route can be enhanced by refreshing breaks in squares with lush vegetation or secluded micro-gardens.

title: Macron's New Caledonia voting reform: A provocation or a faux pas?
summary: The French president had told French daily 'Le Parisien' that he had considered a referendum over an electoral reform in the archipelago, before walking back his comments on Sunday.

title: Papua New Guinea faces 'dramatic situation' as 2,000 feared buried alive under landslide
summary: The United Nations fears that 670 people could have died after the dramatic landslide on Friday. Rescue operations have been complicated by the isolated mountainous area affected where the disaster took place.

title: Paris 2024: Hotels and Airbnb rental prices continue to fall due to oversupply
summary: Some 145,000 homes have been listed on Airbnb for the Olympic and Paralympic Games, compared with 65,000 in normal times. But many have yet to be rented.

title: Russian oil installations: Ukraine's other front
summary: Despite the reticence of the US administration, Ukrainian drones continue to strike at Russian oil sites, including refineries, terminals and depots. According to the Pentagon, they have led to a 14% reduction in Russian fuel production.

title: Israeli army continues Rafah offensive despite international pressure
summary: The bombing of a camp for displaced persons in Rafah on Sunday night caused at least 40 deaths, according to the Gaza Ministry of Health.

title: Georgian parliament committee rejects presidential veto of the divisive 'foreign agents' legislation
summary: The contested law would require news media and non-governmental organizations that get more than 20% of their budget from abroad to register as 'carrying out the interests of a foreign power.'

title: How do you deliver a cancer diagnosis? Medical students train in empathy in drama workshops
summary: At the Montpellier-Nîmes medical school, students train with actors and a director in short improv scenes: a new way of learning how to put interpersonal skills into practice.

title: Ivan Ljubicic: 'It may be easier for the French to pull off a surprse at the Olympics than at the French Open'
summary: The Croatian former world number three, who is director of Ambition 2024 at the French Tennis Federation, talks about his work to restore French tennis to its former glory.

title: Christine Détrez: 'Crushes are a way of reintroducing fantasy, not in a sexual but a romantic sense'
summary: The sociologist and writer used the interviews she conducted with young people aged 13 to 25 to study this form of attraction. A reinvention of romance among the youth says a lot about the new generation's expectations in matters of the heart.

title: French Open 2024: Rafael Nadal loses swansong match
summary: Losing 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 against Germany's Alexander Zverev, Spanish tennis legend Rafael Nadal was beaten in his 116th French Open match, a likely end to his career at the Paris tournament.

title: 1988 to 1992: Four years that could have completely changed France's climate policy
summary: In the late 1980s, France embarked on an ambitious climate policy at the crossroads of environmental concerns and nuclear interests. But the policy was abandoned due to lobbying by industrial companies, particularly the fossil fuel industry.

title: In Kharkiv, an arts center provides unexpected respite from Russian attacks
summary: In the eastern Ukrainian city subjected to daily attacks by the Russian army, the Yermilov Art Center hopes to continue to welcome residents to view its exhibitions as a brief respite from the war.

title: French parliament debates divisive bill on 'aid in dying'
summary: In the first day of two weeks of debates in France's Assemblée Nationale, MPs debated the controversial right-to-die bill, which has been promoted as a key reform of President Emmanuel Macron's second term.

title: World reacts with horror after massacre in Rafah; emergency UN meeting called
summary: An Israeli air strike killed 45 people in an area that had been designated as a 'safe zone' by Israel. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the strike was a 'tragic mistake'.

title: Dutch conservatives, architects of the rise of the far right
summary: Backed by three right-wing and center-right parties, the People's Party for Freedom, populist Geert Wilders' far-right formation, should soon be at the helm of the Netherlands. His allies are betting that he will soon be forced to abandon his radical ideas.
